values.description:
One level per tile \(tunnels or blockers\), using @{557058:10b01d41-a2e9-4a41-a907-e6e2f03b6cd5} 's script. All tiles within a 55m radius of the robot are loaded. That's far enough that no lidars or lights can reach it.

See the world with X1:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2003316297-levels_1.png)
As the robot moves, new levels are loaded. Teleporting it for example:

`ign service -s /world/tunnel_circuit_practice_01/set_pose --reqtype ignition.msgs.Pose --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean --timeout 300 --req 'name: "X1", position: {x: 140, y: 0, z: 1}'`

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2887088677-levels_2.png)
To prevent RGB cameras from seeing empty tunnel holes, the scene background is set to black. That's done only for sensors so that the GUI is still bright to ease debugging:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/131587404-levels_3.png)
This changes the robot's view of the world before entering the tunnel though. It's like it's night outside :wink:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/3066497912-levels_4.png)
values.title: Levels for practice tunnel 1

See the world with X1:

As the robot moves, new levels are loaded. Teleporting it for example:

ign service -s /world/tunnel_circuit_practice_01/set_pose --reqtype ignition.msgs.Pose --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean --timeout 300 --req 'name: "X1", position: {x: 140, y: 0, z: 1}'

To prevent RGB cameras from seeing empty tunnel holes, the scene background is set to black. That's done only for sensors so that the GUI is still bright to ease debugging:

This changes the robot's view of the world before entering the tunnel though. It's like it's night outside

Enabled levels for tunnel circuit practice 03 world

Similar to pull request #205, the background is set to black for the sensors but remains light grey in the gui. I also updated the scene ambient to `0.1` \(down from `0.2`\) as the tunnel tiles now appear bright when the background i pitch dark.

A couple of screenshots:

values.description:
This PR moves the launching of controllers into `team.ign` instead of world launchers like `competition.ign` potentially addressing issue #97. The intention here is that the implementation of UAV controllers is the responsibility of each team. We provide an example here that launches the roll-pitch-yawrate-thrust controller from RotorS. Teams can choose other types of controllers, such as the Lee Position controller from RotorS, but such controllers might need additional sensor data to function properly. Ultimately, the interface for actuating the UAVs in simulation should be `mav_msgs/Actuators`, which is available on the `<robot_name>/command/motor_speed` topic.

Since `team.ign` needs the names and configurations of the robots that have been spawned, it must be launched with the same parameters as `competition.ign`. For example, if the world is launched as such

```
ign launch competition.ign robotName1:=X2_3 robotConfig1:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_3
```
team should be launched with

```
ign launch team.ign robotName1:=X2_3 robotConfig1:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_3
```

This is not ideal, but I can't think of a better way for `team.ign` to know which robots have been spawned.

Edit: Changed title from "Move UAV controllers from competition.ign to team.ign"
values.title: Make launching controllers optional.

summary.raw:
This PR moves the launching of controllers into `team.ign` instead of world launchers like `competition.ign` potentially addressing issue #97. The intention here is that the implementation of UAV controllers is the responsibility of each team. We provide an example here that launches the roll-pitch-yawrate-thrust controller from RotorS. Teams can choose other types of controllers, such as the Lee Position controller from RotorS, but such controllers might need additional sensor data to function properly. Ultimately, the interface for actuating the UAVs in simulation should be `mav_msgs/Actuators`, which is available on the `<robot_name>/command/motor_speed` topic.

Since `team.ign` needs the names and configurations of the robots that have been spawned, it must be launched with the same parameters as `competition.ign`. For example, if the world is launched as such

```
ign launch competition.ign robotName1:=X2_3 robotConfig1:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_3
```
team should be launched with

```
ign launch team.ign robotName1:=X2_3 robotConfig1:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_3
```

This is not ideal, but I can't think of a better way for `team.ign` to know which robots have been spawned.

Edit: Changed title from "Move UAV controllers from competition.ign to team.ign"
summary.html:
This PR moves the launching of controllers into team.ign instead of world launchers like competition.ign potentially addressing issue #97. The intention here is that the implementation of UAV controllers is the responsibility of each team. We provide an example here that launches the roll-pitch-yawrate-thrust controller from RotorS. Teams can choose other types of controllers, such as the Lee Position controller from RotorS, but such controllers might need additional sensor data to function properly. Ultimately, the interface for actuating the UAVs in simulation should be mav_msgs/Actuators, which is available on the <robot_name>/command/motor_speed topic.

Since team.ign needs the names and configurations of the robots that have been spawned, it must be launched with the same parameters as competition.ign. For example, if the world is launched as such

ign launch competition.ign robotName1:=X2_3 robotConfig1:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_3

team should be launched with

ign launch team.ign robotName1:=X2_3 robotConfig1:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_3

This is not ideal, but I can't think of a better way for team.ign to know which robots have been spawned.

Edit: Changed title from "Move UAV controllers from competition.ign to team.ign"

values.description:
Redo of pull request #206

This time the levels are set up so that the tiles are grouped by their x and y positions, i.e. all tiles with the same x pos will be in the same level. So each tile will actually belong to two levels. i.e. one in the ‘row’ level and one in the ‘column’ level. Same logic applies to artifacts and blockers.

Screenshots:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/1051734347-levels_p3_01.png)
![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/935992230-levels_p3_02.png)
values.title: Levels for practice tunnel 03

values.description:
So, while trying to make the scoring test work I can into the following problems:

1. The base station is run alongside simulation, and doesn't have access to ros::Time. This is why the CommsClient has a new "isBasestation" variable and listens to simulation's clock topic. I think this should be fine for teams. If they accidentally declare their client as "isBasestation", then they will try to subscribe to the clock, but the topic won't be available.

2. At first, I thought the /pose topic was missing static objects, and the GameLogicPlugin was never getting the pose of the artifacts. This lead me to make the GameLogicPlugin a SystemPlugin. However, I later realized that levels would only publish poses of objects that are loaded. I left the GameLogicPlugin as a system plugin, because I think it's slightly more efficient.

3. I added, and then tried to remove all instances of debug output. If you see something funky with cout/cerr then please go ahead and correct it.

Whomever tests this, can you also make sure that the ROS api for scoring still works? You should be able to exercise this from the commandline. And, score information should appear on both the ingition and ros /subt/score topics.
values.title: More ros removal debugging

summary.raw:
So, while trying to make the scoring test work I can into the following problems:

1. The base station is run alongside simulation, and doesn't have access to ros::Time. This is why the CommsClient has a new "isBasestation" variable and listens to simulation's clock topic. I think this should be fine for teams. If they accidentally declare their client as "isBasestation", then they will try to subscribe to the clock, but the topic won't be available.

2. At first, I thought the /pose topic was missing static objects, and the GameLogicPlugin was never getting the pose of the artifacts. This lead me to make the GameLogicPlugin a SystemPlugin. However, I later realized that levels would only publish poses of objects that are loaded. I left the GameLogicPlugin as a system plugin, because I think it's slightly more efficient.

3. I added, and then tried to remove all instances of debug output. If you see something funky with cout/cerr then please go ahead and correct it.

Whomever tests this, can you also make sure that the ROS api for scoring still works? You should be able to exercise this from the commandline. And, score information should appear on both the ingition and ros /subt/score topics.
summary.html:
So, while trying to make the scoring test work I can into the following problems:

  1. The base station is run alongside simulation, and doesn't have access to ros::Time. This is why the CommsClient has a new "isBasestation" variable and listens to simulation's clock topic. I think this should be fine for teams. If they accidentally declare their client as "isBasestation", then they will try to subscribe to the clock, but the topic won't be available.

  2. At first, I thought the /pose topic was missing static objects, and the GameLogicPlugin was never getting the pose of the artifacts. This lead me to make the GameLogicPlugin a SystemPlugin. However, I later realized that levels would only publish poses of objects that are loaded. I left the GameLogicPlugin as a system plugin, because I think it's slightly more efficient.

  3. I added, and then tried to remove all instances of debug output. If you see something funky with cout/cerr then please go ahead and correct it.

Whomever tests this, can you also make sure that the ROS api for scoring still works? You should be able to exercise this from the commandline. And, score information should appear on both the ingition and ros /subt/score topics.

values.description:
The `cmd_vel` topic for UAVs does not take velocities, instead it's a combination of roll,pitch,yawrate, and thrust. It's not the most intuitive interface and was added to support the example launch file that uses a joystick to fly the UAVs. This PR renames this topic to `cmd_force` as suggested in
issue #97. 

This PR also prevents launching `ros1_ign_bridge` for topics that don't exist for a given vehicle. For example, X3 doesn't have an odometry topic to be mapped, but `ros1_ign_bridge` was being launched anyway creating `/X3/odom`, which can be confusing.
values.title: Rename cmd_vel to cmd_force for X3 and X4

summary.raw:
The `cmd_vel` topic for UAVs does not take velocities, instead it's a combination of roll,pitch,yawrate, and thrust. It's not the most intuitive interface and was added to support the example launch file that uses a joystick to fly the UAVs. This PR renames this topic to `cmd_force` as suggested in
issue #97. 

This PR also prevents launching `ros1_ign_bridge` for topics that don't exist for a given vehicle. For example, X3 doesn't have an odometry topic to be mapped, but `ros1_ign_bridge` was being launched anyway creating `/X3/odom`, which can be confusing.
summary.html:
The cmd_vel topic for UAVs does not take velocities, instead it's a combination of roll,pitch,yawrate, and thrust. It's not the most intuitive interface and was added to support the example launch file that uses a joystick to fly the UAVs. This PR renames this topic to cmd_force as suggested in issue #97.

This PR also prevents launching ros1_ign_bridge for topics that don't exist for a given vehicle. For example, X3 doesn't have an odometry topic to be mapped, but ros1_ign_bridge was being launched anyway creating /X3/odom, which can be confusing.

values.reason: We will address this after the tunnel circuit competition.

values.description:
Publishes a [sensor_msgs/BatteryState](http://docs.ros.org/melodic/api/sensor_msgs/html/msg/BatteryState.html) message in `/model_name/battery_state`.

Needs:

* https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/145 - merged, being released in ign-msgs 4.5.0
* https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/388 - approved, pending release above
* https://github.com/osrf/ros1_ign/pull/30 - under review

Once this is in, we should document the topic [here](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/api).

values.description:
This PR will output two new log files to `/tmp/ign/logs`:

1. `summary.yml`: This contains high-level information about the run, and should be pretty self-explanatory. If sim_time_duration_sec == 0, then simulation was not started by the team.

2. `score.yml`: This is a file that just has the final score.

@{557058:d30370f4-284a-4762-a32f-25b280051754} , @{557058:ebe9f39d-0ca2-4f29-82cf-6cc3df017384} , @{557058:2f4f0911-c46a-4f3c-92af-650544415846}  The summary file can be used to provide teams with a summary report for a tunnel_circuit submission.
values.title: Output more log files

summary.raw:
This PR will output two new log files to `/tmp/ign/logs`:

1. `summary.yml`: This contains high-level information about the run, and should be pretty self-explanatory. If sim_time_duration_sec == 0, then simulation was not started by the team.

2. `score.yml`: This is a file that just has the final score.

@{557058:d30370f4-284a-4762-a32f-25b280051754} , @{557058:ebe9f39d-0ca2-4f29-82cf-6cc3df017384} , @{557058:2f4f0911-c46a-4f3c-92af-650544415846}  The summary file can be used to provide teams with a summary report for a tunnel_circuit submission.
summary.html:
This PR will output two new log files to /tmp/ign/logs:

  1. summary.yml: This contains high-level information about the run, and should be pretty self-explanatory. If sim_time_duration_sec == 0, then simulation was not started by the team.

  2. score.yml: This is a file that just has the final score.

@Alejo Carballude , @Germán Más , @Patricio Reyna Almandos The summary file can be used to provide teams with a summary report for a tunnel_circuit submission.

values.description:
## Cloudsim Folks 

@{557058:d30370f4-284a-4762-a32f-25b280051754} , @{557058:ebe9f39d-0ca2-4f29-82cf-6cc3df017384} , @{557058:2f4f0911-c46a-4f3c-92af-650544415846} 

I've included you so that you are aware that a "finished" string is sent over the "/subt/start" topic when simulation is finished. This can occur when:

1. A team has achieved all the points.
2. A team has surpassed the allowed artifact report attempts.

You can shutdown simulation, and collect log files, when you see the "finished" string come over the "/subt/start" topic.

## Ian & Carlos

I wrote a test for artifact report limits, but I didn't get time to test termination when the maximum score is achieved. Can one of you write a test for that, and also take this PR over the finish line?
values.title: Implement report limits

summary.raw:
## Cloudsim Folks 

@{557058:d30370f4-284a-4762-a32f-25b280051754} , @{557058:ebe9f39d-0ca2-4f29-82cf-6cc3df017384} , @{557058:2f4f0911-c46a-4f3c-92af-650544415846} 

I've included you so that you are aware that a "finished" string is sent over the "/subt/start" topic when simulation is finished. This can occur when:

1. A team has achieved all the points.
2. A team has surpassed the allowed artifact report attempts.

You can shutdown simulation, and collect log files, when you see the "finished" string come over the "/subt/start" topic.

## Ian & Carlos

I wrote a test for artifact report limits, but I didn't get time to test termination when the maximum score is achieved. Can one of you write a test for that, and also take this PR over the finish line?
summary.html:
Cloudsim Folks

@Alejo Carballude , @Germán Más , @Patricio Reyna Almandos

I've included you so that you are aware that a "finished" string is sent over the "/subt/start" topic when simulation is finished. This can occur when:

  1. A team has achieved all the points.
  2. A team has surpassed the allowed artifact report attempts.

You can shutdown simulation, and collect log files, when you see the "finished" string come over the "/subt/start" topic.

Ian & Carlos

I wrote a test for artifact report limits, but I didn't get time to test termination when the maximum score is achieved. Can one of you write a test for that, and also take this PR over the finish line?

values.description:
Fixed two problems during level testing:

1\) Levels only covered areas in front of the staging area, i.e x > 0. So if the robot moves close to the base station, i.e. green tent, then the tunnels get unloaded. Same thing happens when the robot moves to any negative x position in the map.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2578369611-level_bug_01.png)
2\) levels did not cover z < 0. So if the robot goes down a ramp, the levels are not properly loaded

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/4143453397-level_bug_02.png)
values.title: Fix level size and position for tunnel circuit practice world 01 and 03

summary.raw:
Fixed two problems during level testing:

1\) Levels only covered areas in front of the staging area, i.e x > 0. So if the robot moves close to the base station, i.e. green tent, then the tunnels get unloaded. Same thing happens when the robot moves to any negative x position in the map.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2578369611-level_bug_01.png)
2\) levels did not cover z < 0. So if the robot goes down a ramp, the levels are not properly loaded

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/4143453397-level_bug_02.png)
summary.html:
Fixed two problems during level testing:

1) Levels only covered areas in front of the staging area, i.e x > 0. So if the robot moves close to the base station, i.e. green tent, then the tunnels get unloaded. Same thing happens when the robot moves to any negative x position in the map.

2) levels did not cover z < 0. So if the robot goes down a ramp, the levels are not properly loaded

values.description:
While trying to build the `tunnel_circuit` branch using `catkin build` I found that some things in the `CMakeLists.txt` files weren’t quite right.

This tweaks some of the targets so that `catkin build` can successfully build the subt packages.
values.title: Fix cmake to allow catkin build to work

summary.raw:
While trying to build the `tunnel_circuit` branch using `catkin build` I found that some things in the `CMakeLists.txt` files weren’t quite right.

This tweaks some of the targets so that `catkin build` can successfully build the subt packages.
summary.html:
While trying to build the tunnel_circuit branch using catkin build I found that some things in the CMakeLists.txt files weren’t quite right.

This tweaks some of the targets so that catkin build can successfully build the subt packages.

values.description:
It was noticed that the original roll\_pitch\_yawrate\_thrust\_controller node from the rotors package uses 100% CPU after running for some time, which causes a noticeable drop in RTF. This PR Updates X3 and X4 to use a slightly modified version of the rotors `roll_pitch_yawrate_thrust_controller_node`. Code taken and modified from the [original controller node code](https://github.com/ethz-asl/rotors_simulator/blob/2.2.3/rotors_control/src/nodes/roll_pitch_yawrate_thrust_controller_node.cpp).

Depends on rotors\_control package so you'll need to `apt install ros-melodic-rotors-control`

The only real change I made is adding a node [here](#!/osrf/subt/src/e1225b511ebf70e19be2c2281ae3f9271dde62c7/subt_rotors_controller/src/roll_pitch_yawrate_thrust_controller_node.cpp#lines-108). I don’t see the 100% CPU usage and RTF drop anymore but it’s a mystery to me as to why this resolves the issue \(or maybe it doesn’t\). ~~Marked as WIP as this still needs more testing~~.
values.title: Add custom roll_pitch_yawrate_thrust_controller_node

summary.raw:
It was noticed that the original roll\_pitch\_yawrate\_thrust\_controller node from the rotors package uses 100% CPU after running for some time, which causes a noticeable drop in RTF. This PR Updates X3 and X4 to use a slightly modified version of the rotors `roll_pitch_yawrate_thrust_controller_node`. Code taken and modified from the [original controller node code](https://github.com/ethz-asl/rotors_simulator/blob/2.2.3/rotors_control/src/nodes/roll_pitch_yawrate_thrust_controller_node.cpp).

Depends on rotors\_control package so you'll need to `apt install ros-melodic-rotors-control`

The only real change I made is adding a node [here](#!/osrf/subt/src/e1225b511ebf70e19be2c2281ae3f9271dde62c7/subt_rotors_controller/src/roll_pitch_yawrate_thrust_controller_node.cpp#lines-108). I don’t see the 100% CPU usage and RTF drop anymore but it’s a mystery to me as to why this resolves the issue \(or maybe it doesn’t\). ~~Marked as WIP as this still needs more testing~~.
summary.html:
It was noticed that the original roll_pitch_yawrate_thrust_controller node from the rotors package uses 100% CPU after running for some time, which causes a noticeable drop in RTF. This PR Updates X3 and X4 to use a slightly modified version of the rotors roll_pitch_yawrate_thrust_controller_node. Code taken and modified from the original controller node code.

Depends on rotors_control package so you'll need to apt install ros-melodic-rotors-control

The only real change I made is adding a node here. I don’t see the 100% CPU usage and RTF drop anymore but it’s a mystery to me as to why this resolves the issue (or maybe it doesn’t). Marked as WIP as this still needs more testing.

values.description:
![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/1182955060-artifact_origin_pos.png)
‌

issue #112. The artifact origin is visualized in blue in the screenshot above

‌

Example output from the `/subt/pose_from_artifact_origin` service call:

‌

```
$ rosservice call /subt/pose_from_artifact_origin "robot_name:
  data: 'X1'" 
pose: 
  header: 
    seq: 0
    stamp: 
      secs: 1
      nsecs: 656000000
    frame_id: "artifact_origin"
  pose: 
    position: 
      x: -5.99999999999
      y: 4.99999999993
      z: 0.130161984336
    orientation: 
      x: 2.663248702e-10
      y: 3.95860698837e-11
      z: 1.09694053318e-16
      w: 1.0
success: True
```

values.description:
This now pulls the poses from just the performers \(which the robots are\).

Additionally, it pulls the artifact information using EachNew and the base station and artifact origin directly from the ecm.

values.description:
Basic validator for artifact locations. Loads a performer with a marker, spotlight, and camera which can be moved to various artifacts.

Start a world with `ign launch -v 4 validate_artifacts.ign worldName:=tunnel_circuit_practice_01`

In a separate terminal, scan through the levels until all artifact poses have been retrieved via:  
`ign service -s /artifact/scan --reqtype ignition.msgs.StringMsg --reptype ignition.msgs.StringMsg --timeout 1000 --req 'data: ""'`

Then iterate through artifacts.

`ign service -s /artifact/next --reqtype ignition.msgs.StringMsg --reptype ignition.msgs.StringMsg --timeout 1000 --req 'data: ""'`

The service will respond with the artifact name that you are viewing, and you can use the GUI to look through the two cameras \(one top-down, one at a 45 deg angle\)
values.title: Basic artifact validator

summary.raw:

Then iterate through artifacts.

`ign service -s /artifact/next --reqtype ignition.msgs.StringMsg --reptype ignition.msgs.StringMsg --timeout 1000 --req 'data: ""'`

The service will respond with the artifact name that you are viewing, and you can use the GUI to look through the two cameras \(one top-down, one at a 45 deg angle\)

Start a world with ign launch -v 4 validate_artifacts.ign worldName:=tunnel_circuit_practice_01

In a separate terminal, scan through the levels until all artifact poses have been retrieved via:
ign service -s /artifact/scan --reqtype ignition.msgs.StringMsg --reptype ignition.msgs.StringMsg --timeout 1000 --req 'data: ""'

Then iterate through artifacts.

ign service -s /artifact/next --reqtype ignition.msgs.StringMsg --reptype ignition.msgs.StringMsg --timeout 1000 --req 'data: ""'

The service will respond with the artifact name that you are viewing, and you can use the GUI to look through the two cameras (one top-down, one at a 45 deg angle)

With this fix, competitors will now have run these commands:

```
cd ~/subt_ws/src/subt/docker
docker pull nkoenig/subt-virtual-testbed
./run.bash nkoenig/subt-virtual-testbed tunnel_circuit_practice.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1
```

values.description:
There were topics being bridged when they actually shouldn't exist. With this PR, all topics that come up with `rostopic list` should be valid and usable.

* `front/depth` only published for configs with RGBD cameras
* `odom` only published for UGVs
* `air_pressure`, `magnetic_field` and `motor_speed` only published for UAVs
values.title: Only bridge existing topics

summary.raw:
There were topics being bridged when they actually shouldn't exist. With this PR, all topics that come up with `rostopic list` should be valid and usable.

* `front/depth` only published for configs with RGBD cameras
* `odom` only published for UGVs
* `air_pressure`, `magnetic_field` and `motor_speed` only published for UAVs
summary.html:
There were topics being bridged when they actually shouldn't exist. With this PR, all topics that come up with rostopic list should be valid and usable.

  • front/depth only published for configs with RGBD cameras
  • odom only published for UGVs
  • air_pressure, magnetic_field and motor_speed only published for UAVs

values.description:
Reviewing the implementation of the CI in pipelines I noticed that `catkin_test_results` was not being called so the CI is not reporting errors in the test run. I’m not sure if this was on propose \(just to test build\).

I've also noticed that for properly running tests some dependencies were missing \( \`ros-melodic-interactive-marker-twist-server\` needs ros-testing repo\). The CI is not completely fixed since the whole setup for testing requires installation of `jackal_description`, `husky_description` and `pointegrey_camera_description`. I’m doing that in Jenkins scripts since it requires some complexity for the pointgrey case.

Anyway without an X server running it is going to be difficult to properly run the test suite.
values.title: Enable test report in pipelines: test are failing although CI was green

The CI is not completely fixed since the whole setup for testing requires installation of `jackal_description`, `husky_description` and `pointegrey_camera_description`. values.description:
* Removed all `.urdf.xacro` files except `<robot_name>_from_sdf.xacro`
* Removed dependency on `husky_description`, `jackal_description`, `rotors_description`, `rotors_gazebo`, `subt_description` from package.xml
* Kept `subt_sensors` and `subt_descriptions` packages - I'm not sure if we plan on using these packages in the future or not.

‌

Tested by running a few worlds and I did not notice any error messages. I can also still add robot models in rviz and see the visuals

values.description:
* Added `max_test_score` test back. Somehow it got removed from CMake
* Updated expected robot position from calling the `pose_from_artifact_origin` service to match the new artifact origin pos.
* Fixed computation of artifact position

    * sign was incorrect when calculating the its pose relative to artifact origin
    * the calculated pos was actually relative to X1 instead of X2. Tests passed before because it was within the threshold. The change in the artifact origin pos helped uncover this problem.
values.title: Fix score tests

summary.raw:
* Added `max_test_score` test back. Somehow it got removed from CMake
* Updated expected robot position from calling the `pose_from_artifact_origin` service to match the new artifact origin pos.
* Fixed computation of artifact position

    * sign was incorrect when calculating the its pose relative to artifact origin
    * the calculated pos was actually relative to X1 instead of X2. Tests passed before because it was within the threshold. The change in the artifact origin pos helped uncover this problem.
summary.html:
• Added max_test_score test back. Somehow it got removed from CMake
  • Updated expected robot position from calling the pose_from_artifact_origin service to match the new artifact origin pos.

  • Fixed computation of artifact position

    • sign was incorrect when calculating the its pose relative to artifact origin
    • the calculated pos was actually relative to X1 instead of X2. Tests passed before because it was within the threshold. The change in the artifact origin pos helped uncover this problem.

values.description:
The score and summary logs should now always be generated in `/tmp/ign/logs` directory either when the team calls `/subt/start` or on simulation exit.

The problem was a change I made in pull request #214 to prevent logs from being overwritten on exit but that had the side-effect of only producing logs if the  `/subt/start` service is called.
values.title: Always output score and summary logs

summary.raw:
The score and summary logs should now always be generated in `/tmp/ign/logs` directory either when the team calls `/subt/start` or on simulation exit.

The problem was a change I made in pull request #214 to prevent logs from being overwritten on exit but that had the side-effect of only producing logs if the  `/subt/start` service is called.
summary.html:
The score and summary logs should now always be generated in /tmp/ign/logs directory either when the team calls /subt/start or on simulation exit.

The problem was a change I made in pull request #214 to prevent logs from being overwritten on exit but that had the side-effect of only producing logs if the /subt/start service is called.

values.description:
This pull request modifies the way we’re processing the artifact reports. Right now, we set a maximum number of reports allowed by teams equal to two times the number of artifacts present in the world.

‌

With the current approach, we could end up in situations where a team reports an artifact but the ACK gets lost. Then, the team will eventually retry but will loose one of its artifact tries.

‌

The new behavior addresses this issue by only counting unique reports. In this case, the previous scenario will only count for one artifact report. The unique report is composed by concatenating the report type and its location.

**Reminder**: Update the documentation when we are happy with the ACK approach.
values.title: Do not penalize repeated artifact reports

summary.raw:
This pull request modifies the way we’re processing the artifact reports. Right now, we set a maximum number of reports allowed by teams equal to two times the number of artifacts present in the world.

‌

With the current approach, we could end up in situations where a team reports an artifact but the ACK gets lost. Then, the team will eventually retry but will loose one of its artifact tries.

‌

The new behavior addresses this issue by only counting unique reports. In this case, the previous scenario will only count for one artifact report. The unique report is composed by concatenating the report type and its location.

**Reminder**: Update the documentation when we are happy with the ACK approach.
summary.html:
This pull request modifies the way we’re processing the artifact reports. Right now, we set a maximum number of reports allowed by teams equal to two times the number of artifacts present in the world.

‌

With the current approach, we could end up in situations where a team reports an artifact but the ACK gets lost. Then, the team will eventually retry but will loose one of its artifact tries.

‌

The new behavior addresses this issue by only counting unique reports. In this case, the previous scenario will only count for one artifact report. The unique report is composed by concatenating the report type and its location.

Reminder: Update the documentation when we are happy with the ACK approach.

values.description:
To the dockerfiles, I added the following downloads:

1. subt\_tunnel\_staging\_area
2. Tunnel Tile 3 \(This one is not currently used, but downloading the models doesn't hurt\).
3. Tunnel Tile 4

Removed the version numbers for two models in tunnel\_circuit\_practice\_01.sdf and virtual\_stix.sdf. The version numbers were referencing the latest model versions, and I decided it would be better to have the world files match the docker downloads.

values.description:
Addresses #133.

Needs this PR: https://github.com/osrf/ros1\_ign/pull/34

All cameras now also publish compressed topics. When testing locally, be sure to install the new dependency, `ros-melodic-compressed-image-transport`.

~~Also added camera info for RGBD cameras, which was missing.~~ it wasn't missing
values.title: Compressed images

summary.html:
Addresses #133.

Needs this PR: https://github.com/osrf/ros1_ign/pull/34

All cameras now also publish compressed topics. When testing locally, be sure to install the new dependency, ros-melodic-compressed-image-transport.

Also added camera info for RGBD cameras, which was missing. it wasn't missing

values.description: This PR updates the score files at start and at every artifact report. This helps to guarantee that we don't loose information if something bad (like a crash) happens.
values.title: Update score files more frequently

summary.raw: This PR updates the score files at start and at every artifact report. This helps to guarantee that we don't loose information if something bad (like a crash) happens.
summary.html: This PR updates the score files at start and at every artifact report. This helps to guarantee that we don't loose information if something bad (like a crash) happens.

values.description:
With this PR you can specify the allowed length of a run, in simulation seconds, using the `durationSec:=<seconds>` command line parameter. 

For example, to set the allowed duration to 60 seconds for a tunnel circuit practice:

```
ign launch tunnel_circuit_practice.ign durationSec:=60 robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG1
```

The default duration is 0, which allows a run to last indefinitely. Reaching the duration limit does not stop simulation. It simply stops the ability to score points.

### To Test

1. Run simulation:

    ```
    ign launch tunnel_circuit_practice.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG1 durationSec:=20 -v 4
    ```

2. Echo the `/subt/start` topic:

    ```
    ign topic -e -t /subt/start
    ```

3. Once simulation is up, send the start signal

    ```
    ign service -s /subt/start --reqtype ignition.msgs.Boolean --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean --timeout 2000 --req 'data: true'
    ```

In the second terminal, echoing the `subt/start` topic, you should something similar to:

```
header {
  stamp {
    sec: 31
    nsec: 368000000
  }
}
data: "started"

header {
  stamp {
    sec: 51
    nsec: 372000000
  }
}
data: "finished"
```

In the first terminal, running simulation, you should see:

```
...
[Msg] Run duration set to 20 seconds.
...
[Msg] Scoring has Started
[Msg] Time limit[20s] reached.
[Msg] Scoring has finished. Elapsed real time: 14 seconds. Elapsed sim time: 20 seconds.
```
values.title: Game logic plugin keeps track of allowed run duration

For example, to set the allowed duration to 60 seconds for a tunnel circuit practice:

summary.html:
With this PR you can specify the allowed length of a run, in simulation seconds, using the durationSec:=<seconds> command line parameter.

For example, to set the allowed duration to 60 seconds for a tunnel circuit practice:

ign launch tunnel_circuit_practice.ign durationSec:=60 robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG1

The default duration is 0, which allows a run to last indefinitely. Reaching the duration limit does not stop simulation. It simply stops the ability to score points.

To Test

  1. Run simulation:

    ign launch tunnel_circuit_practice.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG1 durationSec:=20 -v 4

  2. Echo the /subt/start topic:

    ign topic -e -t /subt/start

  3. Once simulation is up, send the start signal

    ign service -s /subt/start --reqtype ignition.msgs.Boolean --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean --timeout 2000 --req 'data: true'

In the second terminal, echoing the subt/start topic, you should something similar to:

header {
  stamp {
    sec: 31
    nsec: 368000000
  }
}
data: "started"

header {
  stamp {
    sec: 51
    nsec: 372000000
  }
}
data: "finished"

In the first terminal, running simulation, you should see:

...
[Msg] Run duration set to 20 seconds.
...
[Msg] Scoring has Started
[Msg] Time limit[20s] reached.
[Msg] Scoring has finished. Elapsed real time: 14 seconds. Elapsed sim time: 20 seconds.

values.description:
Fixes issue #142. The inside of the tunnel entrance is no longer partially invisible.

An updated [subt\_tunnel\_staging\_area](https://app.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/fuel/models/subt_tunnel_staging_area) model was uploaded onto fuel. This PR updates the sdf to always download the latest version of the staging area.

‌

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/3318077404-entrance_inside.png)
values.title: Use latest version of subt tunnel staging area
